Jekyll

Arrays and Loops

Adding arrays

<iframe frameborder=”0” allowfullscreen=”” style=”border: none;position: absolute;top: 0;left: 0;width: 100%;height: 100%;” src=”//www.youtube.com/embed/1frXC3reSGs”></iframe>

1) First code up one iteration of the code that you want jekyll to repeat

2) Then wrap it in a jekyll for loop. Notice how the div with a class of grid is outside the loop, because we don’t want to repeat that every time.

<div class="grid">

    {% for item in page.people %}

        <div class="col-4">
            <h2> John Doe </h2>
            <p>A very smart guy</p>
        </div>

    {% endfor %}

</div>

3) Now replace any info that you want to be different for each with a variable.

<div class="grid">

    {% for item in page.people %}

        <div class="col-4">
            <h2>{{item.name}}</h2>
            <p>{{item.description}}</p>
        </div>

    {% endfor %}

</div>

4) Finally, in the front matter we are going to fill in some extra info to populate my array.

---
layout: default
people:
  - name: John Doe
    description: A smart man
  - name: Jane Smith
    description: A smart woman
---

5) Notice the way only the name has a dash next to them. This is because each time we add a dash we are telling jekyll that we are creating a new item. We also need to make sure the indentation is perfect, otherwise jekyll won’t work as expected.
